title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Ethiopia engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Ethiopia?
preds:
Didn’t see this coming (attempted armed coup in one of the states). Highlights the unknown factor and reason we rate in percentages.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/23/ethiopia-coup-attempt-leaves-army-chief-shot-says-pm

A country focused on stability and economics but also has more displaced people than any other country due to ethnicity/tribalism. Believe Abiy will keep it together but if something happens to him, look out...
https://www.ft.com/content/0fa7e73e-7afe-11e9-81d2-f785092ab560

The recent killing of over 200 Ethiopians by a group of Amharan youths has made headlines recently and paves the way for a possible conflict filled future. Ethiopia has over 80 separate ethnic groups and ethnic conflict tends to be the most violent and extreme when it comes to actions taken against civilians.  This recent killing has a likely chance of spurring conflict among other ethnic groups in the region as either retaliation of preemptive action to gain a territorial or economic foothold over the other. 
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-07/ethiopia-region-demands-probe-into-killings-near-sudan-border

Ethopia's fragile ethnic balance seems to have been disturbed by the election of a more open, less repressive government, and ethnic conflict that has been hidden for decades may bubble to the surface.
Ethiopia is moving somewhat forward economically

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 3.8%. [1] 
- Crowd forecast here is 1%. Inside view: 
- EWP: "In response to a perceived government-sponsored land grab and subversion of Oromo rights, mass public protests broke out across Oromia Region in November 2015, to which Ethiopian security forces responded with violence and repression against civilians." So EWP already counts one such episode in Ethiopia.
- Overall, the situation seems to have improved a lot: "He made peace with long-time regional rivals like Eritrea and Egypt, released journalists, invited back opposition groups, acknowledged that prisoners suffered torture and abuse, and increased the place of women in power. He also promised to open up the economy for private investment, kickstarted a green initiative to transform the capital, and rolled out a visa-on-arrival push for African travelers. Emboldened by these reforms, donor groups returned, with Ethiopia reportedly attracting a record $13 billion of inflows in the past year. Marathoner Feyisa Lilesa, who protested the previous government at the finish line at the Rio Olympics in 2016, also went back. During his East Africa tour last month, French president Emmanuel Macron commended Abiy’s transformative agenda, saying he “profoundly changed” Paris’s vision of Addis Ababa. Human Rights Watch staff who cover Ethiopia were also permitted to visit Ethiopia for the first time in eight years." [2]
- While elections (which can often spark violence) will be held next year, different factions recently signed a peace pact. [3]
- There is of course still communal violence [4][5][6]. Some even argue that it's gotten worse. I'm torn. Overall judgment:
- I don't see a lot of reason to diverge from the base rate. The accounts I read seem similar to what I would expect, given the base rate. Somewhat on the higher side perhaps. I'd estimate 3%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/ethiopia
[2] https://qz.com/africa/1590323/ethiopia-prime-minister-abiy-ahmed-marks-one-year-in-office/
[3] https://www.africanews.com/2019/03/15/ethiopia-parties-sign-pact-ahead-of-2020-polls-pm-stresses-fairness/
[4] https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/10/dozens-killed-ethiopia-ethnic-clashes-181002135619882.html
[5] https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/abiy-year-ethiopia-faces-threat-ethnic-conflict-190401081955303.html
[6] https://www.hrw.org/news/2019/04/09/ethiopia-abiys-first-year-prime-minister-review-conflict-and-internally-displaced
Ethiopia does not have a sufficient security problem to warrant large scale killing as mentioned in the question
